question.text: For an ideal solution of two components <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, which of the following is true?

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> interaction is stronger than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. interactions

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> interactions are identical

solution.text: When two components <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> form an ideal solution, the interactions <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>–</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo> </mo><mo>–</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo> </mo><mi>and</mi><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo> </mo><mo>–</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> are similar due to which no heat is absorbed or released and also volume after mixing remains same.
